statements.text: Health care should be considered a human right.
Health care shouldn't be considered a human right.
Declaring healthcare as a human right is economically unfeasible.
Declaring healthcare as a human right isn't economically unfeasible.
Health care, if considered a human right, forces others in society to bear costs they did not cause.
Health care, if considered a human right, forceses others in society to bear costs they did cause.
Food is a basic human necessity and a human right, and farmers are similarly expected to provide for the rest of humanity.
Food isn't a basic human necessity and a human right, and farmers are similarly expected to provide for the rest of humanity.
The US has opposed [1] international calls to consider food as a human right.
The US hasn't opposed [1] international calls to consider food as a human right.

The USA is an outlier as it refuses to ratify many otherwise-globally-accepted treaties such as the Conventaion against Torture [2], the Arms Trade Treaty [3], Convention on the Rights of the Child [4], Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities [5], and even the treaty on treaties [6].

The USA isn't an outlier as it refuses to ratify many otherwise-globally-accepted treaties such as the Conventaion against Torture [2], the Arms Trade Treaty [3], Convention on the Rights of the Child [4], Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities [5], and even the treaty on treaties [6].
Governments frequently act as monopsonistic buyers [7] in the agricultural market to ensure food security, even to the detriment of farmers.
Governments frequently don't act as monopsonistic buyers [7] in the agricultural market to ensure food security, even to the detriment of farmers.
Unlike healthcare, sourcing, obtaining, and preparing food can be done independently, without relying on others.
Unlike healthcare, sourcing, obtaining, and preparing food can't be done independently, without relying on others.
Citizens bear the cost of health care through taxation, which is a fair payment in exchange for the government's provision of services.
Citizens don't bear the cost of health care through taxation, which is a fair payment in exchange for the government's provision of services.
Healthcare professionals also bear the cost of health care as a human right through a loss in wage.
Healthcare professionals also don't bear the cost of health care as a human right through a loss in wage.
Health care professionals cannot negotiate for higher wages [8] if the government is the sole employer of doctors and nurses.
Health care professionals can negotiate for higher wages [8] if the government is the sole employer of doctors and nurses.
Doctors in the private sector earn a higher income [9] than those working in the public sector.
Doctors in the private sector don't earn a higher income [9] than those working in the public sector.
If doctors start exiting the healthcare market, the government is likely to incentivize them to stay within the system to maintain supply.
If doctors don't start exiting the healthcare market, the government is likely to incentivize them to stay within the system to maintain supply.
The government similarly sustains a network of professionals and maintains an extensive infrastructure to ensure the people's right to a fair trial [10].
The government similarly doesn't sustain a network of professionals and maintains an extensive infrastructure to ensure the people's right to a fair trial [10].

Paying for and maintaining a network of public hospitals and professionals through taxation to ensure the people's right to health care is similar to sustaining public defenders [11] and prosecutors [12].

Paying for and maintaining a network of public hospitals and professionals through taxation to ensure the people's right to health care isn't similar to sustaining public defenders [11] and prosecutors [12].
More than 90% [13] of the cases never get to a jury, and the prosecutors have enormous leeway in selecting which transgressions they will bring to trial.
More than 90% [13] of the cases never don't get to a jury, and the prosecutors have enormous leeway in selecting which transgressions they will bring to trial.
This doesn't contradict the fact that every defendant has the right to an attorney, state-funded if necessary.
This contradicts the fact that every defendant has the right to an attorney, state-funded if necessary.
Doctors often relocate [14] abroad to access higher salaries in the private market.
Doctors often don't relocate [14] abroad to access higher salaries in the private market.
Passion often drives career choices, not just money; people are motivated by their love for the work, and not necessarily salaries.
Passion often drives career choices, just money; people are motivated by their love for the work, and not necessarily salaries.
Taxation funds government, which allocates resources based on citizens' demands.
Taxation funds government, which doesn't allocate resources based on citizens' demands.
Being unable to opt out of paying taxes and not having a say in how they are allocated equals compulsion to support something unwanted.
Being unable to opt out of paying taxes and having a say in how they are allocated equals compulsion to support something unwanted.
Forcing individuals to pay for something they do not support violates their individual liberty to choose how to spend their money.
Forcing individuals to pay for something they do support violateses their individual liberty to choose how to spend their money.
A person can have a say in how taxes are spent by voting for a representative who aligns with their desired allocation [15] of funds.
A person can't have a say in how taxes are spent by voting for a representative who aligns with their desired allocation [15] of funds.
Majority rule, making decisions based on preferences of the majority, may devolve into mob rule and not adequately protect minority rights.
Majority rule, making decisions based on preferences of the majority, may devolve into mob rule and adequately protect minority rights.
Representatives are accountable to their constituents and consider their preferences when allocating public funds.
Representatives aren't accountable to their constituents and consider their preferences when allocating public funds.
Other individuals' poor lifestyle choices force healthy people to bear the costs.
Other individuals' poor lifestyle choices don't force healthy people to bear the costs.
Individual choices, like smoking, raise the risk of future illnesses and drive up healthcare expenses.
Individual choices, like smoking, don't raise the risk of future illnesses and drive up healthcare expenses.
Individual choices, such as smoking, already come at a greater cost to people due to increased taxation [16] by the state.
Individual choices, such as smoking, already None come at a greater cost to people due to increased taxation [16] by the state.
The tax burden of universal healthcare is likely to be the same for every citizen, regardless of their smoking habits.
The tax burden of universal healthcare isn't likely to be the same for every citizen, regardless of their smoking habits.
Taxation on unhealthy foods can potentially reduce diet-related health conditions [17] such as obesity and heart disease, while also generating additional revenue to fund public healthcare systems.
Taxation on unhealthy foods can't potentially reduce diet-related health conditions [17] such as obesity and heart disease, while also generating additional revenue to fund public healthcare systems.
People are often coerced into adopting unhealthy habits such as smoking due to aggressive marketing.
People aren't often coerced into adopting unhealthy habits such as smoking due to aggressive marketing.
Tobacco advertisements make smoking appear appealing [18], increasing the likelihood of people taking up the habit.
Tobacco advertisements don't make smoking appear appealing [18], increasing the likelihood of people taking up the habit.
Many countries around the world have complete or partial bans [19] on tobacco advertising.
Many countries around the world don't have complete or partial bans [19] on tobacco advertising.
It is not the government's responsibility to regulate or monitor people's vulnerability to drug use through persuasive advertisements.
It is the government's responsibility to regulate or monitor people's vulnerability to drug use through persuasive advertisements.
It cannot be stated with certainty that unhealthy habits such as smoking wholly cause a given disease.
It can be stated with certainty that unhealthy habits such as smoking wholly cause a given disease.
Some people may be genetically predisposed to specific diseases, meaning that their genes increase their likelihood of developing certain health conditions, regardless of their lifestyle habits.
Some people may not be genetically predisposed to specific diseases, meaning that their genes increase their likelihood of developing certain health conditions, regardless of their lifestyle habits.
Unhealthy working conditions, such as those faced by coal miners, can increase a person's risk of developing diseases.
Unhealthy working conditions, such as those faced by coal miners, can't increase a person's risk of developing diseases.

While it may be difficult to attribute a particular disease entirely to smoking, there is a strong correlation [20] between smoking and various health conditions, such as lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and heart disease.

While it may be difficult to attribute a particular disease entirely to smoking, there doesn't be a strong correlation [20] between smoking and various health conditions, such as lung cancer, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and heart disease.
The risk of developing smoking-related diseases decreases [21] after quitting smoking, supporting the link between smoking and disease.
The risk of developing smoking-related diseases doesn't decrease [21] after quitting smoking, supporting the link between smoking and disease.
If treated as a civil right, people won't take responsibility for unhealthy behaviors.
If treated as a civil right, people will take responsibility for unhealthy behaviors.
Free healthcare may lead to neglect of personal health due to lack of financial consequences, resulting in a burden on the government funding the care.
Free healthcare may not lead to neglect of personal health due to lack of financial consequences, resulting in a burden on the government funding the care.
The lack of financial consequences does not equate to the absence of physical repercussions.
The lack of financial consequences equates to the absence of physical repercussions.
No one would purposely hurt themselves because they could get healthcare for free.
No one wouldn't purposely hurt themselves because they could get healthcare for free.
People may not take preventative measures for their health, such as regular check-ups and screenings, if they do not perceive a significant financial cost from future illnesses.
People may take preventative measures for their health, such as regular check-ups and screenings, if they do not perceive a significant financial cost from future illnesses.
Without financial consequences, people may engage in riskier behaviors that lead to illness or injury, such as unhealthy diets or dangerous recreational activities.
Without financial consequences, people may not engage in riskier behaviors that lead to illness or injury, such as unhealthy diets or dangerous recreational activities.
Most people are naturally deterred from engaging in unhealthy or risky behavior due to a fear of injury or death.
Most people aren't naturally deterred from engaging in unhealthy or risky behavior due to a fear of injury or death.
A lack of free health care may enhance a person's natural aversion to risky behavior.
A lack of free health care may not enhance a person's natural aversion to risky behavior.
Risk-taking people are likely to behave the same way regardless of their financial situation.
Risk-taking people aren't likely to behave the same way regardless of their financial situation.
Countries can create incentives [22] that nudge people towards better life choices.
Countries can't create incentives [22] that nudge people towards better life choices.
The goal to restrict people from engaging in any behavior that might jeopardize their health is unrealistic.
The goal to restrict people from engaging in any behavior that might jeopardize their health isn't unrealistic.
If one fails to fulfill their obligation of taking care of their body, it should be fair for them to lose their right to health care.
If one fails to fulfill their obligation of taking care of their body, it shouldn't be fair for them to lose their right to health care.
Modern societies require citizens to pay for the consequences of others' actions, from funding law enforcement and correctional facilities to financing litter collection.
Modern societies don't require citizens to pay for the consequences of others' actions, from funding law enforcement and correctional facilities to financing litter collection.
It is ethically sound for society to assist its citizens, even if it may require reductions in earnings for a private individual.
It isn't ethically sound for society to assist its citizens, even if it may require reductions in earnings for a private individual.
Situations where an individual benefits at the disproportionate cost of society, especially when it's an intentional decision, should be minimized.
Situations where an individual benefits at the disproportionate cost of society, especially when it's an intentional decision, shouldn't be minimized.
Societies trade individual freedoms for security; policing is a traded freedom, and so should be healthcare.
Societies trade individual freedoms for security; policing doesn't be a traded freedom, and so should be healthcare.
Costs borne by individuals for sustaining health care can be minimized.
Costs borne by individuals for sustaining health care can't be minimized.
Paying a cost for security is a response to the external risk of being a victim of crime, and this is not analogous to healthcare.
Paying a cost for security is a response to the external risk of being a victim of crime, and this is analogous to healthcare.
Shouldering the costs of health care because of a similar expectation within policing would only serve to increase the overall cost burden.
Shouldering the costs of health care because of a similar expectation within policing wouldn't only serve to increase the overall cost burden.
Whether something exists or how widespread its practice is at any given point in time is not an indication of its social utility [23].
Whether something exists or how widespread its practice is at any given point in time is an indication of its social utility [23].
Citizens may be unwilling contributors to law enforcement, because of dissatisfaction, through mandatory taxation.
Citizens may not be unwilling contributors to law enforcement, because of dissatisfaction, through mandatory taxation.
Society is responsible for their choices even if they are poor ones.
Society is responsible for their choices even if they aren't poor ones.

Society has an obligation to promote health for everyone, especially since it already subsidizes [24] behaviors and industries that contribute to poor health (e.g. tax cuts for underpaying corporations and subsidies for sugar [25] and fossil fuels).

Society doesn't have an obligation to promote health for everyone, especially since it already subsidizes [24] behaviors and industries that contribute to poor health (e.g. tax cuts for underpaying corporations and subsidies for sugar [25] and fossil fuels).
Unhealthy individuals tend to utilize a disproportionately large share of healthcare resources.
Unhealthy individuals don't tend to utilize a disproportionately large share of healthcare resources.
Statistically, 1% of the population consistently uses [26] up to 20% of the total health care expenditure in the US, and 5% uses almost 50%.
Statistically, 1% of the population consistently doesn't use [26] up to 20% of the total health care expenditure in the US, and 5% uses almost 50%.
Healthcare should be apportioned by need rather than each person receiving the same amount.
Healthcare shouldn't be apportioned by need rather than each person receiving the same amount.
If these 1% or 5% have much more serious diseases than the rest, it wouldn't be fair not to give them the support they need.
If these 1% or 5% have much more serious diseases than the rest, it would be fair not to give them the support they need.
An aging population drives up [27] health care costs, as older adults tend to have more health problems and require more medical services.
An aging population doesn't drive up [27] health care costs, as older adults tend to have more health problems and require more medical services.
Accepted human rights entitle people to make claims on the resources of others, it just requires prudence in distributing resources, and not, a justification to discard the right.
Accepted human rights entitle people to make claims on the resources of others, it just doesn't require prudence in distributing resources, and not, a justification to discard the right.
Some human rights are negative rights [28], meaning that they only require that other people don't negate them.
Some human rights are negative rights [28], meaning that they only require that other people do negate them.
The right to live is a negative right, meaning the government is encouraged to do nothing to infringe upon it, unless necessary.
The right to not live is a negative right, meaning the government is encouraged to do nothing to infringe upon it, unless necessary.
The idea that human rights can only be exercised within certain limits or under certain conditions is not unreasonable; health insurance normally does have certain applicability restrictions [29].
The idea that human rights can only be exercised within certain limits or under certain conditions is unreasonable; health insurance normally does have certain applicability restrictions [29].
All people will need health care at some point in their lives, and whatever they pay for it today is something they will benefit from in the future.
All people won't need health care at some point in their lives, and whatever they pay for it today is something they will benefit from in the future.
There are compounding factors that influence a persons health that are independent of choice.
There aren't compounding factors that influence a persons health that are independent of choice.
People born into poverty are likely to have a less nutritious diet [30], making them more susceptible to diseases.
People None bear into poverty are likely to have a less nutritious diet [30], making them more susceptible to diseases.
An accident can impact [31] a person's long-term health.
An accident can't impact [31] a person's long-term health.
A person's geographic location might place them at the center of an epidemic [32].
A person's geographic location mightn't place them at the center of an epidemic [32].
Individuals have a responsibility to seek out accurate information and make informed decisions about their health.
Individuals don't have a responsibility to seek out accurate information and make informed decisions about their health.
Many health conditions, such as heat disease and diabetes, can be managed or even prevented through lifestyle choices and medical interventions.
Many health conditions, such as heat disease and diabetes, can't be managed or even prevented through lifestyle choices and medical interventions.
People are still responsible for making choices on how to manage the preexisting health conditions and what types of treatments to pursue.
People aren't still responsible for making choices on how to manage the preexisting health conditions and what types of treatments to pursue.
Older people are likely to suffer [33] from a greater number of health issues as a natural consequence of their age.
Older people aren't likely to suffer [33] from a greater number of health issues as a natural consequence of their age.
Widespread provision of health care in a society improves its economy.
Widespread provision of health care in a society doesn't improve its economy.
Universal health care would be incredibly costly and therefore detrimental to the economy.
Universal health care wouldn't be incredibly costly and therefore detrimental to the economy.
Many countries provide universal healthcare [34], showing that any detrimental economic effects are not substantial.
Many countries provide universal healthcare [34], showing that any detrimental economic effects are substantial.
Canada has a universal health care system [35], and forecasts a fiscal surplus [36] in 2023.
Canada doesn't have a universal health care system [35], and forecasts a fiscal surplus [36] in 2023.
The cost forecast for universal health coverage in California was more than [37] the state's entire budget.
The cost forecast for universal health coverage in California wasn't more than [37] the state's entire budget.
There is evidence to suggest that a single-payer system [38] allows for negotiations that would actually drive down [39] the price of services.
There isn't evidence to suggest that a single-payer system [38] allows for negotiations that would actually drive down [39] the price of services.

Many countries (e.g., most in Europe) provide healthcare equally to all their citizens funding it with taxes. In this way everyone pays taxes proportionally to what they earn, and everybody gets healthcare. Nobody has to go bankrupt because they can't afford healthcare or medical cost, and the country receives all the money needed to run the healthcare system, which does not "run out" of resources until wages are paid and supplies are bought.

Many countries (e.g., most in Europe) provide healthcare equally to all their citizens funding it with taxes. In this way everyone pays taxes proportionally to what they earn, and everybody gets healthcare. Nobody has to go bankrupt because they caafford healthcare or medical cost, and the country receives all the money needed to run the healthcare system, which does not "run out" of resources until wages are paid and supplies are bought.
Universal healthcare is too expensive.
Universal healthcare isn't too expensive.
Universal healthcare requires a large amount of funding to cover the costs of providing healthcare to every citizen, regardless of their ability to pay.
Universal healthcare doesn't require a large amount of funding to cover the costs of providing healthcare to every citizen, regardless of their ability to pay.
The US health care cost has been growing independent of universal coverage, and recently accounted for nearly 20% of the GDP expenditure. [40]
The US health care cost hasn't been growing independent of universal coverage, and recently accounted for nearly 20% of the GDP expenditure. [40]
Taxes may need to be increased to fund a universal healthcare system, which could lead to opposition from taxpayers who do not want to see an increase in their tax burden.
Taxes may need to be increased to fund a universal healthcare system, which could lead to opposition from taxpayers who do want to see an increase in their tax burden.
Universal healthcare in the U.S is estimated to cost over $30 trillion [41] over a decade.
Universal healthcare in the U.S isn't estimated to cost over $30 trillion [41] over a decade.
Universal healthcare can be affordable through cost control measures [42], which some countries have implemented.
Universal healthcare can't be affordable through cost control measures [42], which some countries have implemented.
Many cost-control strategies within public healthcare systems have led to wage cuts [43].
Many cost-control strategies within public healthcare systems haven't led to wage cuts [43].
The primary driver of healthcare cost is insurance companies [44], which can be contained in a publicly run healthcare system.
The primary driver of healthcare cost isn't insurance companies [44], which can be contained in a publicly run healthcare system.
Insurance companies are known to overcharge [45] customers even when operating within universal healthcare systems.
Insurance companies aren't known to overcharge [45] customers even when operating within universal healthcare systems.
Health insurance providers charge customers a premium that exceeds the actual costs they pay to hospitals, driven by their profit motive.
Health insurance providers don't charge customers a premium that exceeds the actual costs they pay to hospitals, driven by their profit motive.
Patents in the pharmaceutical industry significantly contribute to healthcare costs by driving up drug prices [46].
Patents in the pharmaceutical industry significantly don't contribute to healthcare costs by driving up drug prices [46].
Insurance companies are not accountable to the people, unlike governments, and are therefore able to overcharge customers.
Insurance companies are accountable to the people, unlike governments, and are therefore able to overcharge customers.
Insurance companies often negotiate lower prices [47] than the published chargemaster [48] rates.
Insurance companies often don't negotiate lower prices [47] than the published chargemaster [48] rates.
The lack of a universal health care is significantly more expensive [49] and puts an even heavier burden on individuals than the taxes that would be used to supply everyone with healthcare.
The lack of a universal health care isn't significantly more expensive [49] and puts an even heavier burden on individuals than the taxes that would be used to supply everyone with healthcare.
The combined economic impact of ill-health currently sits at a 77.5 billion a year [50] for the UK economy.
The combined economic impact of ill-health currently doesn't sit at a 77.5 billion a year [50] for the UK economy.
This is lower than the UK's health care budget, of 145 billion [51].
This isn't lower than the UK's health care budget, of 145 billion [51].
US government's spending on healthcare outstrips UK government spending [52], both in terms of the proportion of its GDP, and in terms of how much it spends per head.
US government's spending on healthcare doesn't outstrip UK government spending [52], both in terms of the proportion of its GDP, and in terms of how much it spends per head.
Individuals' poor personal decisions, such as poor dental hygiene and consumption of sugary foods, can outweigh the impact of government-funded healthcare.
Individuals' poor personal decisions, such as poor dental hygiene and consumption of sugary foods, can't outweigh the impact of government-funded healthcare.
Studies and international health organisations agree that healthcare drives economic growth.
Studies and international health organisations don't agree that healthcare drives economic growth.
A US study found that [53] improving public health care funding improved income, GDP, and labor productivity.
A US study didn't find that [53] improving public health care funding improved income, GDP, and labor productivity.
The world Bank claims that increasing healthcare is beneficial to the economy [54], and is a "foundational investment in economic growth".
The world Bank claims that increasing healthcare isn't beneficial to the economy [54], and is a "foundational investment in economic growth".
The Council of Economic Advisers (CEA) predicts [55] that a 1.5% increase in healthcare spending would lead to a 2-8% increase in GDP.
The Council of Economic Advisers (CEA) doesn't predict [55] that a 1.5% increase in healthcare spending would lead to a 2-8% increase in GDP.
The link between health care and economic growth is complex and multifaceted, and may not always be straightforward.
The link between health care and economic growth is complex and multifaceted, and may always be straightforward.

While health care may drive economic growth overall, it may not necessarily benefit all segments of society equally, and may exacerbate existing inequalities in access to health care and economic opportunities.

While health care may drive economic growth overall, it may necessarily benefit all segments of society equally, and may exacerbate existing inequalities in access to health care and economic opportunities.
An improved economy is not a characteristic of a human right.
An improved economy is a characteristic of a human right.
Human rights are based on fundamental principles of dignity, equality, and freedom that are independent of economic considerations.
Human rights aren't based on fundamental principles of dignity, equality, and freedom that are independent of economic considerations.
Human rights and a positive economy are directly correlated, implying that a positive economy is not just a characteristic, but a requirement for the existence of human rights.
Human rights and a positive economy are directly correlated , implying that a positive economy is just a characteristic, but a requirement for the existence of human rights.
Healthcare systems that are not universal are inefficient [56], and create loss for an economy.
Healthcare systems that are universal are inefficient [56], and create loss for an economy.
The US, the only developed country without universal healthcare [57], spends more [58] on health care than any other nation with universal health care provision.
The US, the only developed country without universal healthcare [57], doesn't spend more [58] on health care than any other nation with universal health care provision.
The ACA [59] has directly lead to vast costs increases [60] across the US [61], with the average cost increase at about 160%.
The ACA [59] hasn't directly lead to vast costs increases [60] across the US [61], with the average cost increase at about 160%.
Providing universal health care will harm the healthcare industry.
Providing universal health care won't harm the healthcare industry.
Innovation within the healthcare industry is likely to reduce.
Innovation within the healthcare industry isn't likely to reduce.
A privately-run company's incentive to make profit incentivizes them to invest into research and development [62]; a public-hospital does not have the same incentive.
A privately-run company's incentive to make profit incentivizes them to invest into research and development [62]; a public-hospital does have the same incentive.
Most investment into healthcare is publicly funded [63], this is unlikely to change.
Most investment into healthcare isn't publicly funded [63], this is unlikely to change.
A universal healthcare system will allow for better coordination of healthcare services, reducing waste and inefficiency.
A universal healthcare system won't allow for better coordination of healthcare services, reducing waste and inefficiency.
A government-run healthcare system can ensure consistent payment [64] to all providers, preventing outlier providers from setting excessive prices due to a client's limited information.
A government-run healthcare system can't ensure consistent payment [64] to all providers, preventing outlier providers from setting excessive prices due to a client's limited information.
A universal healthcare system simplifies decision-making for the consumer.
A universal healthcare system doesn't simplify decision-making for the consumer.
In a fragmented insurance system, consumers normally have little visibility [65] on prices across different health insurance plans.
In a fragmented insurance system, consumers normally don't have little visibility [65] on prices across different health insurance plans.
Governments have started to require private providers [66] to publish complete price-lists, thereby increasing the access to information for consumers.
Governments haven't started to require private providers [66] to publish complete price-lists, thereby increasing the access to information for consumers.
Medical professionals' income is likely to decline within a publicly run healthcare system.
Medical professionals' income isn't likely to decline within a publicly run healthcare system.
A publicly run healthcare system may prioritize cost control over income growth for medical professionals, leading to reduced income for these professionals.
A publicly run healthcare system may not prioritize cost control over income growth for medical professionals, leading to reduced income for these professionals.
With a larger pool of patients, medical professionals in a publicly run healthcare system may have to work longer hours or see more patients per day to maintain their income levels.
With a larger pool of patients, medical professionals in a publicly run healthcare system may not have to work longer hours or see more patients per day to maintain their income levels.
Medical professionals often belong to the highest income bracket [67] in their nation, even when the healthcare system is publicly run.
Medical professionals often don't belong to the highest income bracket [67] in their nation, even when the healthcare system is publicly run.
Non-universal healthcare systems often have high administrative costs, as insurance companies and healthcare providers negotiate prices and coverage.
Non-universal healthcare systems often don't have high administrative costs, as insurance companies and healthcare providers negotiate prices and coverage.
Health insurance providers often overcharge [68] customers for administrative charges.
Health insurance providers often don't overcharge [68] customers for administrative charges.
Not-for-profit hospitals in the U.S have been reported to have a lower admin cost [69] than for-profit private hospitals in the U.S.
Not-for-profit hospitals in the U.S haven't been reported to have a lower admin cost [69] than for-profit private hospitals in the U.S.
Government bureaucracies can also generate excessive administrative costs [70] through inefficient management.
Government bureaucracies can't also generate excessive administrative costs [70] through inefficient management.
Insurance companies already operate on very thin margins [71], therefore to important that they have negotiating power in order remain competitive.
Insurance companies already don't operate on very thin margins [71], therefore to important that they have negotiating power in order remain competitive.

Without a universal healthcare system, patients lack the bargaining power to negotiate lower prices for medical procedures and treatments, which can lead to high costs for both patients and the healthcare system.

Without a universal healthcare system, patients don't lack the bargaining power to negotiate lower prices for medical procedures and treatments, which can lead to high costs for both patients and the healthcare system.
Government regulation controlling for exorbitant pricing can exist [72] even in the absence of a universal healthcare system.
Government regulation controlling for exorbitant pricing can't exist [72] even in the absence of a universal healthcare system.
Prescription drugs in the U.S are more expensive than other places due to a lack [73] of single-payer negotiation.
Prescription drugs in the U.S aren't more expensive than other places due to a lack [73] of single-payer negotiation.
Government provision of health care is likely to create a very inefficient system.
Government provision of health care isn't likely to create a very inefficient system.
State provision or financing of healthcare may facilitate corruption and artificially inflate health insurance costs.
State provision or financing of healthcare may not facilitate corruption and artificially inflate health insurance costs.
Direct healthcare financing makes health insurance optional, which prioritizes protecting the general population's health over increased health insurance costs.
Direct healthcare financing doesn't make health insurance optional, which prioritizes protecting the general population's health over increased health insurance costs.
Public healthcare systems are likely to be corrupt.
Public healthcare systems aren't likely to be corrupt.
Public healthcare [74] can operate without corruption, and there is no proven link between corruption levels [75] and healthcare outcomes across countries.
Public healthcare [74] can't operate without corruption, and there is no proven link between corruption levels [75] and healthcare outcomes across countries.
Sweden's healthcare [76] is publicly funded, and Sweden is one of the least corrupt countries [77] in the world.
Sweden's healthcare [76] isn't publicly funded, and Sweden is one of the least corrupt countries [77] in the world.
Private providers can also be corrupt by billing patients or the state fraudulently [78].
Private providers can't also be corrupt by billing patients or the state fraudulently [78].
Government officials, who command significant influence, can embezzle funds [79] for personal gain.
Government officials, who command significant influence, can't embezzle funds [79] for personal gain.
US healthcare is the world's most expensive [80], while government-funded systems in Europe offer lower costs and universal access.
US healthcare isn't the world's most expensive [80], while government-funded systems in Europe offer lower costs and universal access.
Government bureaucracy complicates healthcare and raises costs, while the free market [81] provides better healthcare to more people.
Government bureaucracy doesn't complicate healthcare and raises costs, while the free market [81] provides better healthcare to more people.
Competition [82] in the free market leads to innovation and improved services.
Competition [82] in the free market doesn't lead to innovation and improved services.
America's private healthcare industry leads the world [83] in medical research and innovation.
America's private healthcare industry doesn't lead the world [83] in medical research and innovation.
The administrative costs of government-run healthcare systems are often much higher than [84] those in the free market.
The administrative costs of government-None run healthcare systems are often much higher than [84] those in the free market.
In the USA, one of the wealthiest nations in the world, citizens spend more per capita [85] on healthcare than citizens of countries with socialized healthcare.
In the USA, one of the wealthiest nations in the world, citizens don't spend more per capita [85] on healthcare than citizens of countries with socialized healthcare.
Unregulated for-profit healthcare corporations overprice insulin [86], making it unaffordable for those who need it.
Unregulated for-profit healthcare corporations don't overprice insulin [86], making it unaffordable for those who need it.
Universal healthcare systems are associated with long waiting-times [87] for patients.
Universal healthcare systems aren't associated with long waiting-times [87] for patients.
Long waiting times, due to demand exceeding supply, incentivizes bribery to skip lines.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: An inherent right [122] is innate and exists naturally, independent of laws or society, and healthcare does not fit this definition.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Rights are determined by society, and individuals are not born with inherent rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are no inherent human rights at the philosophical level, as all rights are defined and granted by humans, including different definitions chosen by various groups, cultures, and nations.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Although one's place of birth and the actions of others can impact the degree to which their rights are respected, everyone possesses inherent and inalienable [123] human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Human rights are universal and indivisible, meaning that they cannot be separated or denied to some individuals without undermining the rights of all.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is no such thing as a natural right. The very theory of natural rights is self-evidently the philosophical work of humans.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A right can only be a natural right, best described as self-evident in the U.S. Declaration of Independence [124]: "They are endowed by their creator with certain unalienable right."

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Education, similar to health care, is beneficial, but is not an inherent human right that exists in nature.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Rights are inherent to a person and not something to be provided at another's expense.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The idea that rights cannot be provided at another's expense can be seen as overly individualistic and neglectful of the broader societal benefits that can come from ensuring that everyone's rights are fulfilled.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Medical conditions can interfere with a persons ability to access all other human rights. If the poor are denied healthcare for lack of money, they are being denied other human rights for lack of money. That goes against the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Forcing someone to provide healthcare denies their right to liberty since they cannot refuse to serve.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care, while not an inherent right, but can be considered an economic, social, and cultural right, or a positive right. [125]

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The U.S. Constitution does not provide for "Positive Rights" [126] such as the right to health care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Supreme court rulings support this view, that the Constitution is a charter of negative rather than positive liberties [127].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If human rights are only considered valid as formal legal rights, it undermines the universality of these principles due to the contingent historical and political nature [128] of legal norms.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A legal document, such as a constitution, is based upon universal principles; declaring health care to be a human right would simply result in an amendment to the constitution.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: If a right isn't codified as formal legal right, there is no use-value [129] to the right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The UN argues that [130] the enjoyment of all human rights is interlinked so categories of rights such as civil and political rights or economic, social and cultural rights make little sense.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The Universal Declaration of Human Rights no longer [131] makes any distinction between civil rights and economic, social, and cultural rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care, as a human right, can be argued to be similarly interlinked to other fundamental human rights, such as the right to life.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Justice, Equality, and Freedom of speech are beneficial for humanity even while not echoed in nature.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Access to justice is considered to be a human right [132], while not necessarily grounded in nature.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: All humans are considered to be equal, even though they might not be equal at birth [133].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Equality among humans is echoed in nature, hierarchy is a social construct.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Justice is a product of the supposed natural right to self defense [134] and the right to property [135].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Freedom of speech is a derivative of the supposed natural right to freewill [136].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Access to health care is a fundamental necessity for leading a productive life, both financially and otherwise, and is therefore important principle to aspire towards.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care is a finite resource, and therefore cannot be inherent to each person.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: "Human right" doesn't mean equal application. It just means guaranteed opportunity for.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This suggests that there isn't a right to health care, merely a right to pursue health care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It does not make sense to try and provide health care to every person equally, as circumstances differ between people.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Medical inputs necessary for a person's treatment are often limited in supply.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Fiercely contested components (e.g. organ donations) should be offered in terms of clinical suitability and likelihood of improvement, not equally.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Restrictive regulations pertaining to organ donation that maximize health outcomes, are controversial because they treat people as means to an end without taking personal views into consideration.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Allocating finite resources to have the most positive impact reflects the belief that improving the overall population's health is a priority, similar to the belief that all individuals deserve equal access to health improvements.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Advances in medical technology and research are constantly expanding the range of available medical treatments and inputs.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Government investments in healthcare infrastructure and research can increase the availability of medical inputs over time.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Rights cannot guarantee access to things that cannot be guaranteed to exist. For instance, a person can have a right to life but not to a life-sustaining medicine, as medicines may sometimes be inaccessible.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Various resources, while being finite, are considered to be human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Water, a finite resource, is defined by the UN [137] as a human right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 2010, the United Nations General Assembly recognized [138] access to safe and clean drinking water and sanitation as a human right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Clean and safe water is essential for human survival and health as it enables basic hygiene and necessary daily tasks, reducing the risk of illness and disease.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care does not occur naturally. If water comes through a pipe or in a bottle you still pay for it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Water is a human right whether it is found naturally, paid for by the bottle [139], or delivered by pipe.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries, such as the US, do not [140] recognize water as a human right, while acknowledging that it may be essential.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is a lot easier to provide someone with clean water than with quality health care, so this is not a good comparison.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Food and shelter are finite resources, but generally accepted as basic human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Food and shelter is both essential to life and not provided by government, and yet almost nobody freezes or starves to death in the western world simply for want of food [141] or shelter [142].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the USA, almost 16 million [143] children lived in food-insecure households in 2012. Childhood hunger causes an "increase in both physical and psychological health problems [144]".

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care is unique because it is much more expensive than any other necessary good like food or water. It is also not readily available from nature.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Cost should not decide what is a right, but only cause a limit to the extent a right can be upheld.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This claim proves the underlying lack of feasibility of proscribing positive rights to a good or service. Availability absolutely dictates access: if it's not there you can't have it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is an insufficient number [145] of health care professionals [146] working an insufficient number of man-hours to provide the level of care desired by universal healthcare advocates.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care systems do not suffer from a lack of physicians, but from an uneven distribution [147] of physicians.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There is an international consensus that health care is a human right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The International Bill of Human Rights [148] includes health care as a human right [149].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights also declares [150] health care as an essential right, that must be accessible to all.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights is legally binding [151] when ratified.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Twenty four countries and four non-UN members [152] have not ratified the treaty.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The USA, a major world power, has not ratified [153] the treaty.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A lack of ratification by a major power, for whatever reason, signals certain principles, otherwise considered paramount, to be contestable.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The USA recognizes parts of some non-ratified treaties as customary international law [154] and binding upon them as such [155].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In 1948, the UN adopted the Universal Human Rights Declaration. Article 25 [156] (p. 52) states: "Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services."

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Access to health care has been recognized as a right, as codified by The Geneva Conventions [157], even in times of war.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Medical care is different from health care; treatment for a life-threatening affliction is not the same as annual check-ups.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care is complicated and made up of several sub-parts. For example, accessibility to nutritional advice could be considered part of health care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Healthcare is sometimes defined as [158] "the organized provision of medical care to individuals or a community". This suggests there is little difference between the terms, as health care just refers to the provision of medical care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Rights are determined by society and subject to what is feasible. If something cannot be provided, it cannot be considered a right in that society.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to healthcare is not to any specific form of healthcare but to what is available [159].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Governments distribute hospitals geographically and provide emergency services for transportation to hospitals, but to expect all these services to be provided for free is unfair.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Lack of food availability does not nullify the right to food, just as depletion of medical resources does not negate the right to treatment. Both are essential for survival and wellbeing, and should be replenished when possible.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A right is what is owed or allowed to people by their society. Nothing can be a right in general, but only within a particular context or society.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Rights are inherent to human beings and not dependent on geography, culture, or time. Variations in rights across societies would imply a variable value of human life, which is discriminatory.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Different societies and cultures have different values and beliefs, which can lead to different interpretations of what rights are and what they entail.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to access professional healthcare in times of need has the same foundation as the right to not be killed, starved, or deprived of basic necessities, as both are universally desired by humans.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Human rights don't exist, but only particular and providable rights in each society - i.e., in a society where healthcare is providable, it will be a right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There are no globally applicable human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Just because healthcare is not possible to provide, doesn't mean it's not a human right; human rights are violated all the time, but that doesn't make them any less human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Countries being invaded cannot provide the human right to life to their citizens anymore, but this is not a valid reason to consider the human right to life invalid.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Healthcare lacks a universal standard for defining what is adequate, which can vary across cultures and time periods.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Human rights are often defined as inalienable, fundamental rights inherent to all human beings "regardless of their nation [160]". Therefore, the overarching principle cannot be bound by location or type of society.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: You don't have a right to another's labor.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Several other human rights rely on the labor of others, and the resources of the state, to be upheld.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to food [161], and the right to housing [162], are internationally defined and accepted [163], but require labor, money, and effort.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Most people, all over the world, are required to pay for food and housing; arguments for universal healthcare suggest that it should be free for all citizens.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to food does not imply that governments have an obligation to hand out free food to everyone who wants it, or a right to be fed. This is not a human right in the same way that health care is suggested to become a human right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The ICESCR [164] says "the right to adequate food is realised when every man, woman and child, alone or in community with others, have the physical and economic access at all times to adequate food or means for its procurement."

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: These rights are different, they are positive not negative [165], and are economic, social, and cultural. [166]

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Three generations of human rights [167] includes these rights as human rights (second and third generations).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Economic, social and cultural rights [168] are not always considered full human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: While there is consensus that human rights encompasses a wide variety of rights [169] such as the right to a fair trial, free speech, or a right to education, there is disagreement [170] about which of these particular rights should be included within the general framework of human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: These also shouldn't be considered rights. Rights should not impose any obligation on others, they should only require non-interference.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to vote requires the state to offer every voter suitable means and locations to vote, including election officials and judges.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Voting, in most jurisdictions, is optional [171].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Not all [172] nations hold elections.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Most states have to appoint thousands of poll clerks [173] across the district in order to hold an election.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state provides citizens with free counsel [174] in order to uphold their right to a fair trial.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Free legal counsel ensures equal access to legal representation, necessary for a fair trial, particularly for those who cannot afford it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to representation [175] is triggered only when the state charges you in criminal court, therefore it exists with constraints unlike publicly provisioned health care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Access to health care by a public practitioner can also be placed within reasonable constraints.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The state's allocation of resources to specific initiatives cannot be used as a proxy to determine whether something is a human right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to education [176] is a similar human right which is accepted and functioning. It is similar in that it requires a functioning economy, trained paid professionals, and has a private alternative.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Education is limited by age and level, while healthcare cannot be similarly limited.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Healthcare can also be limited for elective procedures [177] and/or limited to crucial non-elective procedures [178].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Most states do not provide free-education beyond secondary school.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Human rights have limitations. For example, the right to life can be limited in cases of self-defense, and the right to freedom of speech can be limited in cases of hate speech or breaching legally binding agreements.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The UN Right To Education [179] has been agreed by 166 states, and has been in effect since 1976.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Healthcare costs more than Education.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In the UK, Healthcare costs [180] 149.7 billion (19%), but Education only costs 85.3 billion (11%). (USA [181]:  22% / 15%).

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The most international definition of a human right is that of the UN, which includes Education in it's 1948 Universal declaration of Human Rights [182]

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: No individual may compel another individual to provide a service to them; universal health care depends on the state compelling healthcare professionals to provide their service.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Doctors can opt to work in the private sector, as opposed to, working for the state.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many governments require their citizens to perform mandatory labor in specific circumstances for the benefit of society.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Citizens in many jurisdictions are required to perform mandatory jury service [183].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: During times of war, governments have been known to impose mandatory military conscription [184].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Mandatory labor can perpetuate systems of inequality and injustice, particularly if certain groups are disproportionately targeted or affected.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Mandatory labor is a form of exploitation and violates individuals' rights to freedom and autonomy.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Citizens demand and expect the services of the police, and the state obliges, in times of insecurity.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Being fairly compensated for the provision of your labor is a human right, and it conflicts with the declaration of health care as a right.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care professional working in the public sector are fairly compensated [185] for their labor.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Citizens have the free choice to not enter [186] a paid-contractual relationship with the state as their employer.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: In cases of emergencies, doctors are often required to provide their services without an assurance of payment.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to freely render (or not render) services is a consistent based on a set of rights that are not adorned by government, but understood to be universal.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many accepted Human rights have conflicts [187] between them.  In a developed nation, the Procedural Right to getting paid could co-exist with the Substantive [188] right to healthcare.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Providing healthcare as a human right ensures citizens' access to life and obligates the state to provide it to all.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Universal healthcare, as provided by the state, protects everyone's right to life.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Universal healthcare, as a human right, is counterproductive if it cannot be fully provided by the government.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Treating universal healthcare as a human right enables citizens to sue the government for violating it, which is costly and ineffective if the government cannot provide such healthcare practically.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries [189], both rich and poor, already provide universal healthcare, demonstrating that it is an achievable standard to require and not an impossible one.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Although the right to life is a human right, the right to health is not. Therefore, the state should only provide the minimum necessary to sustain a person's life and not go beyond that.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Universal healthcare does not provide equal access; long wait times for treatment are common, as seen in Canada [190], and Britain [191].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Private healthcare is an option in countries with public healthcare systems for those who prefer not to wait.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Universal healthcare is not feasible.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A universal healthcare system can exist in numerous forms [192].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Universal health care, in any form, necessitates substantial government spending, which is typically financed through increased taxation.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: There exist mixed systems, such as in Germany [193]. Monetary interest persists, yet everyone obtains health care regardless of the income.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A quality public healthcare service benefits both those who can afford private treatment and those who cannot, especially in less developed countries with limited access to affordable care.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Emergency life-sustaining treatment may be feasible, but a broad definition that encompasses all things improving well-being would be impractical.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many countries [194] already do provide healthcare that improves wellbeing rather than just emergency treatment.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: It is difficult to quantify the extent to which health care is a right, which makes the idea of universal health care impractical.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Defining a universal right to health care is challenging due to varying societal standards for adequate care and no consensus on essential health care services.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Many other human rights have semi-vague quantifications, and still function well. The specifics can be left to each government.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The human right to education is only required to be [195] "made generally available", and higher education has to be "equally accessible to all on the basis of merit". Education is a well functioning human right despite the minimum/maximum quantity being unspecified.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The right to work has no specific qualifications [196] like hours worked or pay, it merely specifies "free choice of employment, to just and favourable conditions of work and to protection against unemployment." and protects from discrimination.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A right cannot be vague or it is meaningless.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This argument is fallacious as it is predicated on other human rights being accepted as human rights.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Low quality healthcare is better than none.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Low quality medical interventions can be dangerous [197] for the patient.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Access to some healthcare services, even if they are low quality, can be crucial in emergency situations or in preventing the spread of infectious diseases.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Advancements in technology and medicine makes it feasible to provide health care to all.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: Technological advancements have paved the pay for newer and cheaper modes of health delivery, such as telehealth [198].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The advanced technology has only served to increase the cost, not lessen it.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The cost of heath care per capita has been steadily increasing [199].

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: A good deal of modern medical costs for the hospitals is administration [200] needed to handle payments from virtually limitless insurance companies.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The World Health organisation (WHO) has released a report [201] which maps the ways that all countries can sustainably achieve universal healthcare.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: The 49 "low-income countries" that would find it hardest to adopt universal healthcare have been given a roadmap [202] which includes Increasing the efficiency of revenue collection, reprioritising government budgets, innovating financing, and receiving development assistance for health supported by the Millennium Development Goals.

source_retrieval.name: Kialo
source_retrieval.text_raw: This report estimates that from 20% to 40% of all health spending is currently wasted through inefficiency [203], and urges these savings to be pursued instead of cutting funding or leaving some citizens with no care at all.

source_retrieval.text_raw: Health care as a a human right impacts the people's ability to access other fundamental rights such as the right to freedom and liberty.
